text: TDA Progress Report 42-119
label: BODY

text: November 15, 1994
label: BODY

text: An Algorithm for Extraction of Periodic Signals
label: HH1

text: From Sparse, Irregularly Sampled Data
label: TITLE

text: J. Z. Wilcox
label: BODY

text: Tracking Systems and Applications Section
label: BODY

text: Temporal gaps in discrete sampling sequences produce spurious Fourier compo-
label: BODY

text: nents at the intermodulation frequencies of an oscillatory signal and the temporal
label: BODY

text: gaps, thus signiﬁcantly complicating spectral analysis of such sparsely sampled data.
label: BODY

text: A new fast Fourier transform (FFT)-based algorithm has been developed, suitable
label: BODY

text: for spectral analysis of sparsely sampled data with a relatively small number of
label: BODY

text: oscillatory components buried in background noise. The algorithm’s principal idea
label: BODY

text: has its origin in the so-called “clean” algorithm used to sharpen images of scenes
label: BODY

text: corrupted by atmospheric and sensor aperture eﬀects. It identiﬁes as the signal’s
label: BODY

text: “true” frequency that oscillatory component which, when passed through the same
label: BODY

text: sampling sequence as the original data, produces a Fourier image that is the best
label: BODY

text: match to the original Fourier map. Unlike the clean algorithm, it performs the
label: BODY

text: search in the Fourier space. The algorithm has generally met with success on trials
label: BODY

text: with simulated data with a low signal-to-noise ratio, including those of a type simi-
label: BODY

text: lar to hourly residuals for Earth orientation parameters extracted from VLBI data.
label: BODY

text: For eight oscillatory components in the diurnal and semidiurnal bands, all compo-
label: BODY

text: nents with an amplitude-noise ratio greater than 0.2 were successfully extracted for
label: BODY

text: all sequences and duty cycles (greater than 0.1) tested; the amplitude-noise ratios
label: BODY

text: of the extracted signals were as low as 0.05 for high duty cycles and long sam-
label: BODY

text: pling sequences. When, in addition to these high frequencies, strong low-frequency
label: BODY

text: components are present in the data, the low-frequency components are generally
label: BODY

text: eliminated ﬁrst, by employing a version of the algorithm that searches for noninte-
label: BODY

text: ger multiples of the discrete FFT minimum frequency.
label: BODY

text: I. Introduction
label: HH1

text: In observational sciences like astronomy, it frequently happens that data are available at an unevenly
label: BODY

text: spaced set of sampling times. The analyst may wish to extract from these data certain periodic compo-
label: BODY

text: nents for which the frequencies are not precisely known. In fact, signal extraction from sparse or unevenly
label: BODY

text: sampled data may prove crucial to the successful exploitation of large data sets assembled at considerable
label: BODY

text: expense over many years. If the data acquisition process is characterized by a regular or nearly periodic
label: BODY

text: succession of gaps during which no data are taken, sidelobes will occur at frequencies corresponding to the
label: BODY

text: intermodulation products of the various signal and gap frequencies, giving rise to spurious signals in the
label: BODY

text: Fourier map. The situation is aggravated by the inevitable presence of noise. In recent years, a number
label: BODY

text: of authors have developed methods based on Lomb’s normalized periodogram to deal with problems of
label: BODY

text: this kind. A set of references and an implementation of Lomb’s method are provided in [1]. A recent
label: BODY

text: article studied the eﬀect of temporal windows on observed solar oscillation parameters [2]. However,
label: BODY

text: there appears to be no currently available method to search for periodic signals with a low signal-to-noise
label: BODY

text: ratio and unknown frequencies spanning a potentially broad spectral range; nor does there exist a clear
label: BODY

text: understanding of the mathematical limits on the kinds of information that might be extracted from such
label: BODY

text: data.
label: BODY

text: This article describes a new mathematical procedure for extraction of periodic signals from incomplete
label: BODY

text: data sets. The procedure addresses a situation of particular interest in which only a relatively small
label: BODY

text: number of periodic components are present within a noisy background. Although it may not be possible
label: BODY

text: even in principle to extract a large array of broadband signals from sparsely sampled data, the fact that
label: BODY

text: only a small number of components are present makes it possible to extract the components in a manner
label: BODY

text: that eﬀectively eliminates ambiguity.
label: BODY

text: The main idea of the new procedure comes from the so-called
label: BODY

text: “clean” algorithm [3], which has been extensively used within the astronomical community to sharpen
label: BODY

text: images of scenes corrupted by atmospheric and sensor aperture eﬀects. Clean algorithms have been most
label: BODY

text: successful in cleaning up maps of images created by a small number of intense sources. The location of
label: BODY

text: the most intense point source is identiﬁed with the highest peak in the scene’s “dirty” map. By modeling
label: BODY

text: the eﬀects of the atmosphere and sensor aperture (or other intermediate ﬁlters) on the image of a single
label: BODY

text: localized source, the resulting point spread function is subtracted oﬀ, and a point reconstruction added
label: BODY

text: to a clean map. The process is repeated for successively smaller peaks.
label: BODY

text: Analogous to the clean algorithm, the new algorithm identiﬁes the strongest oscillatory component and
label: BODY

text: produces a Fourier image of this signal as it would be registered if it were sampled in the same manner
label: BODY

text: as the actual data. Unlike in the clean algorithm, a search for the component is performed in Fourier
label: BODY

text: space. That frequency is identiﬁed as the frequency of the strongest oscillatory component whose Fourier
label: BODY

text: image is the best match to the Fourier map of the actual data. The image is subtracted from the original
label: BODY

text: Fourier map. The diﬀerence between the old map and the subtracted image is a new residual map, and
label: BODY

text: the amplitude and frequency of the generating signal are recorded as contributors to the clean map.
label: BODY

text: The algorithm has generally met with success in trials with simulated data, including those of a type
label: BODY

text: similar to hourly residuals for Earth orientation parameters extracted from VLBI data. Some eight signal
label: BODY

text: components in the diurnal and semidiurnal bands with amplitudes varying by an order of magnitude were
label: BODY

text: added to a background of Gaussian noise on the same order of magnitude as the oscillatory signal. For
label: BODY

text: a 2-year-long sampling sequence and 20-percent duty cycle (the duty cycle is deﬁned as the ratio of the
label: BODY

text: length of time during which the data was taken to the sequence’s total length), all components with an
label: BODY

text: amplitude–noise ratio greater than about 0.2 were successfully extracted; for a 100-percent duty cycle,
label: BODY

text: the extracted amplitude–noise ratio was as low as 0.05. To minimize central processing unit (CPU) time
label: BODY

text: (important for long data sequences), the algorithm uses fast Fourier transforms (FFTs) on uniformly
label: BODY

text: spaced time markers. The data arrays have zeroes added into the temporal gaps and into the appended
label: BODY

text: region (which is added to make the array size equal to a power of two). The CPU time scales as a
label: BODY

text: constant ×N ×log N, where the constant depends on the eﬃciency of the search for the signal oscillatory
label: BODY

text: frequencies. For N = 218 time markers and 8 cleaning steps, the required CPU time on a VAX-class
label: BODY

text: machine was on the order of several minutes. The frequency resolution is 1/T, where T is the sampling
label: BODY

text: sequence length. For cases when a more precise frequency determination is required, or when in addition
label: BODY

text: to the high (i.e., diurnal and semidiurnal) frequencies, the data contains low-frequency components, a
label: BODY

text: noninteger version of the algorithm has been developed. The noninteger version constructs the Fourier
label: BODY

text: image as a function of frequencies that are not integer multiples of the discrete FFT minimum frequency.
label: BODY

text: An additional search, performed by using a functional minimum-ﬁnding algorithm, extends the search to
label: BODY

text: noninteger frequency values. Compared to the integer algorithm, the noninteger algorithm determines
label: BODY

text: the signal frequencies with greatly improved accuracy. It also consumes more CPU time, depending on
label: BODY

text: the desired accuracy and on the spectral content of the original data.
label: BODY

text: Section II describes the algorithm; Section III describes results of simulation experiments; and the
label: BODY

text: Appendix describes the algorithm extension to frequencies that are not equal to discrete FFT frequencies.
label: BODY

text: II. The Algorithm
label: HH1

text: The data are sampled in a sequence that consists of discrete observation sessions (or windows, on
label: BODY

text: the order of one day) between which there are large gaps (on the order of several days). Within each
label: BODY

text: session, data are sampled at uniformly spaced discrete time intervals that are integers of some minimum
label: BODY

text: δt (in our case, 1 hr). The set of hour markers at which the data are taken deﬁnes the sampling function
label: BODY

text: S(tn), which assumes values of 1 or 0 depending upon whether or not a data value was acquired at that
label: BODY

text: particular time. The data deﬁne the array D(tn), in which the entries where no data have been taken
label: BODY

text: have been set to zero. The hour markers are tn = n δt, n = 0, 1, · · · , N −1, where N is the total number of
label: BODY

text: markers in the sampling sequence of duration T = N δt. Note that, to use the FFT, it is most convenient
label: BODY

text: for N to be chosen equal to a power of 2.
label: BODY

text: Sampling at discrete intervals creates a situation whereby frequencies beyond the maximum resolved
label: BODY

text: frequency (Nyquist, equal in our case to 1/2δt) are aliased (or “folded back”) into the lowest frequency
label: BODY

text: region. In addition, the presence of periodic or nearly periodic gaps in the data sequence leads to the
label: BODY

text: appearance of sidelobes and spurious spectral peaks at the signal and gap intermodulation frequencies.
label: BODY

text: The sidelobes are also aliased into the lowest spectral region. To remove the sidelobe eﬀect, the algorithm
label: BODY

text: produces a Fourier map of the actual data and identiﬁes the strongest oscillatory component. It calculates
label: BODY

text: a Fourier image of this signal ﬁltered through the same sequence, S(tn), as the actual data, and subtracts
label: BODY

text: it from the original Fourier map to produce a residual map. The most obvious candidate for the strongest
label: BODY

text: component is a frequency with the biggest peak in the original Fourier map.
label: BODY

text: Occasionally, however,
label: BODY

text: the biggest peak occurs at one of the intermodulation frequencies. Therefore, the “true” modulation
label: BODY

text: frequency is found to be that frequency which when passed through S(tn) is the best match (including
label: BODY

text: the sidelobe structure) for the original Fourier map.
label: BODY

text: Let Ml designate the least squares function:
label: BODY

text: Ml ≡
label: BODY

text: |DS(k) −
label: BODY

text: a±l f S
label: BODY

text: where the sum over k is a sum over all (discrete) frequencies, ωk ≡2πk/(Nδt).
label: BODY

text: The DS(k)
label: BODY

text: is a
label: BODY

text: discrete Fourier transform of D(tn), and the second term on the right-hand side of Eq. (1) is a Fourier
label: BODY

text: representation of a candidate oscillatory signal of frequency ωl taken over the sampling function S(tn).
label: BODY

text: That is, f S
label: BODY

text: l (k) is a Fourier transform of fl(tn) S(tn), where the periodic function fl(tn) = exp
label: BODY

text: −2π i nl
label: BODY

text: Note that if there were no gaps in the data (i.e., if S(tn) consisted of an uninterrupted series of data
label: BODY

text: points), then f S
label: BODY

text: l (k) would consist of a single Kronecker delta, δl,k. However, because of the window-gap
label: BODY

text: structure of S(tn), the f S
label: BODY

text: l (k)’s will have sideband components, similar to sideband components of DS(k).
label: BODY

text: The al’s specify amplitudes of the Fourier components f S
label: BODY

text: l (k). It is important that the Fourier repre-
label: BODY

text: sentation of a candidate oscillatory signal sums over both the positive and negative frequency indexes to
label: BODY

text: account for signal phase. To see this, assume that the contribution of the lth oscillatory component to
label: BODY

text: data is
label: BODY

text: Al cos
label: BODY

text: 2π n l
label: BODY

text: N + φl
label: BODY

text: where φl is phase. The contribution to the Fourier map is
label: BODY

text: eiφlf S
label: BODY

text: −l(k) + e−iφlf S
label: BODY

text: l (k)
label: BODY

text: Because Eq. (3) consists of both a positive and its complex conjugate negative frequency components, so
label: BODY

text: must the Fourier image, P
label: BODY

text: ± a±l f S
label: BODY

text: ±l(k), in Eq. (1).
label: BODY

text: The index l that minimizes Ml as a function of l is identiﬁed as the signal’s true frequency. To perform
label: BODY

text: the minimization, DS(k)’s and f S
label: BODY

text: l (k)’s are computed (for all k’s and candidate l’s). The coeﬃcients a±l
label: BODY

text: are computed from the following complex conjugate relationships for spectral strengths at ±l locations
label: BODY

text: in the Fourier map:
label: BODY

text: DS(l) = a−lf S
label: BODY

text: −l(l) + al f S
label: BODY

text: l (l)
label: BODY

text: DS(−l) = a−lf S
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: By combining Eqs. (4a) and (4b), the a±l’s are computed for the candidate l. The computed a±l’s are
label: BODY

text: substituted into Eq. (1), whose minimization yields the optimal index l for the frequency of the strongest
label: BODY

text: oscillatory component. Note that the use of the positive and negative l allows for reconstruction of the
label: BODY

text: signal phase. By comparing Eqs. (3) and (4), the signal phase φl is given by the following expression:
label: BODY

text: tan φl = Im a−l
label: BODY

text: Re a−l
label: BODY

text: Hence, the use of the above-described procedure allows one to determine signal phase.
label: BODY

text: The above relationships, Eqs. (4) and (5), were derived by relating the spectral strengths at ±l lo-
label: BODY

text: cations. It is possible to formally derive Eq. (4) by minimization of Eq. (1) as a function of al. The
label: BODY

text: minimization is performed in the Appendix, together with the extension of the algorithm to noninteger l
label: BODY

text: values. Note also that the use of the a±l’s computed from Eq. (4) permits complete subtraction of the
label: BODY

text: spectral strengths at the ±l locations; if the data consist of a single frequency, then one subtraction yields
label: BODY

text: a residual at the level of the machine round-oﬀerror or background noise, whichever is bigger.
label: BODY

text: For data modulated with several frequencies, multiple applications of the algorithm are necessary.
label: BODY

text: Equations (1)–(5) will apply, except that on the (i + 1)th iteration, DS(k) is replaced by a residual array
label: BODY

text: (yi(k)) that has resulted from the ith iteration, yi(k) ≡yi−1(k) −P
label: BODY

text: ± a±li f S
label: BODY

text: ±li(k), where li is the
label: BODY

text: optimal index that minimizes Ml at the ith iteration, yi−1(k) is the residual array that has resulted from
label: BODY

text: the (i −1)th iteration, and yo(k) ≡DS(k) is the Fourier transform of the original data. With multiple
label: BODY

text: iterations, it may sometimes be desirable to subtract the spectral peaks in fractions. That is (as is a
label: BODY

text: common practice in the application of the clean algorithm), one subtracts at each iteration only a fraction
label: BODY

text: of the image that has been constructed by using the peak’s full strength. However, the phase relationship
label: BODY

text: between the subtracted a±l’s should be the same as that computed from Eq. (4). Sidelobes associated with
label: BODY

text: one frequency can contribute signal at another frequency. Subtracting the peaks in fractions permits one
label: BODY

text: to correct for sidelobe contributions associated with other signal frequencies. In any case, the algorithm
label: BODY

text: ﬁrst removes (or partially removes) the most intense component (including sidebands due to the window-
label: BODY

text: gap structure), forms the residual array, and treats the residual as a new set of data. The process is
label: BODY

text: iterated to yield a desired number of oscillatory components.
label: BODY

text: III. Results and Discussion
label: HH1

text: Two versions of the above-described general procedure have been implemented and tested on simulated
label: BODY

text: data. In the ﬁrst version, the oscillatory signal that minimizes Eq. (1) consists of two integers, ±l, as
label: BODY

text: in Eq. (3). This version works very well when all modulation frequencies are equal (or nearly equal) to
label: BODY

text: discrete multiples of 1/T. If T is the total length of the sampling sequence, then the spacing for the
label: BODY

text: resolved frequencies is 1/T, corresponding to the resolution parameter of τ 2/T for an oscillatory signal
label: BODY

text: with period τ.
label: BODY

text: Thus, this version provides a suﬃcient resolution for relatively high frequencies, say,
label: BODY

text: τ < 0.01 T (in which case, the resolution is better than 1 percent). Because the strongest components are
label: BODY

text: extracted ﬁrst, the accuracy with which these components are extracted impacts the extraction success of
label: BODY

text: less intense components. The integer version works best when all (relatively rapid) modulation amplitudes
label: BODY

text: are about the same order of magnitude. The second version of the algorithm searches for frequencies that
label: BODY

text: are not integer multiples of 1/T (or, equivalently, the frequency indices are not integer multiples of 1/N).
label: BODY

text: This version allows one, at the expense of increased CPU time, to determine the oscillatory frequencies
label: BODY

text: with greatly improved accuracy. This version must be used for analysis of data with strong low-frequency
label: BODY

text: components.
label: BODY

text: A. Integer Frequency Index
label: HH1

text: The integer version was tested with success on many diﬀerent types of simulated monochromatic as well
label: BODY

text: as multifrequency signals; the modulations were imbedded in Gaussian noise. The success of frequency
label: BODY

text: extraction depends on the number of modulation frequencies, the length and structure of the sampling
label: BODY

text: sequence (including length, number, and regularity of individual observational sessions), and noise level.
label: BODY

text: For a monochromatic signal (data sampled hourly), the modulation frequencies ranged from those
label: BODY

text: corresponding to periods of 4 hr to those corresponding to the length T of the data sequence. Table 1
label: BODY

text: summarizes the results of the simulations for S(tn) consisting of 20 and 200 1-day-long, periodically
label: BODY

text: repeating sessions separated by several day-long gaps. The residual has been reduced to a background
label: BODY

text: level by using a single subtraction step for signal-to-noise amplitude ratios as low as 0.17 and 0.04,
label: BODY

text: respectively, when the duty cycle was 1; the minimum values of the successfully extracted ratios were 0.3
label: BODY

text: and 0.1, and 0.5 and 0.125, for the duty cycles of 0.2 and 0.1, respectively. Here, the duty cycle has been
label: BODY

text: deﬁned as the ratio of the number of days on which data were recorded to the total number of days in
label: BODY

text: the observation period (e.g., for a 1-day-long observation session registered on every 5th day, the duty
label: BODY

text: cycle is 1/5). Results of simulations for nonperiodic sampling sequences were similar, except that the
label: BODY

text: extraction tended to be successful even at somewhat higher noise levels. This is not unexpected, since
label: BODY

text: constructive interference (leading to strong sidelobes) is less.
label: BODY

text: Results of simulation experiments for a signal consisting of several modulation frequencies are sum-
label: BODY

text: marized in Tables 2 and 3 and Fig. 1. Eight oscillatory components (four in the semidiurnal band and
label: BODY

text: four in the diurnal band) with amplitudes varying by an order of magnitude between the strongest and
label: BODY

text: weakest component were added to a background of Gaussian noise. Typical S(tn)’s consisted of 70, 140,
label: BODY

text: and 740 1-day-long observation sessions (data sampled hourly) separated by 4-day- (duty cycle 0.2) and
label: BODY

text: 9-day-long (duty cycle 0.1) gaps. The noise amplitude was as high as 100 (the amplitudes of the oscilla-
label: BODY

text: tory components ranged from 3 to 23). The amplitudes and relative phase of the simulated signals are
label: BODY

text: summarized in Table 2. To demonstrate the resolution for the extracted signals, the table also summa-
label: BODY

text: rizes the results of the extraction process for the 140–data day, 0.2–duty cycle sampling sequence, with
label: BODY

text: the noise level equal to the amplitude of the strongest component. All eight components were extracted
label: BODY

text: within their resolution accuracy (for T = 216 hr, the resolution τ 2/T ≃0.002 and 0.008 for semidiurnal
label: BODY

text: and diurnal bands, respectively) in eight iteration steps. Figure 1(a) shows the original data, and Figs.
label: BODY

text: 1(b), (c), and (d) show, respectively, the original, residual, and clean Fourier maps.
label: BODY

text: Results of simulations for the same oscillatory components but diﬀerent observation parameters are
label: BODY

text: summarized in Table 3. To investigate the eﬀect of excess iterations, the number of cleaning steps used
label: BODY

text: was 10. In Table 3, the symbol s designates an oscillatory component extracted within its expected
label: BODY

text: resolution, c designates an extraction of a previously extracted component, i designates extraction at
label: BODY

text: one of the intermodulation frequencies, and n designates noise (any frequency higher than 1/6 h−1 was
label: BODY

text: considered a noise). A component may be extracted twice (or several times) because of our use of the full
label: BODY

text: spectral strength DS(±l) [Eq. (4)] for the subtraction of the Fourier image. The strength DS(±l) consists
label: BODY

text: of contributions from the lth oscillatory component as well as from sidelobes produced by other frequencies

text: (sidelobes produced by one frequency contribute spurious strength at other frequencies). Therefore, the
label: BODY

text: use of the full DS(±l) may add (or subtract) signal strength at the lth or other frequency. The appearance
label: BODY

text: of c’s (c stands for correction) in Table 3 signiﬁes that some of the excess strength has been recovered on
label: BODY

text: subsequent iteration of the algorithm (other side eﬀects may be errors at other frequencies or noise). The
label: BODY

text: number of successful extractions decreases with decreasing T, decreasing duty cycle, and increasing noise.
label: BODY

text: In Table 3, successful extractions range from all eight (low noise, long T case) to two components (70 data
label: BODY

text: days, a 0.1 duty cycle, noise amplitude of 100, corresponding to the minimum extracted amplitude–noise
label: BODY

text: ratio of 0.2). For 140 and 740 data days, the critical amplitude–noise ratio is 0.1 and 0.07, respectively,
label: BODY

text: when the duty cycle is 0.2; the ratio is somewhat less (higher) for higher (lower) duty cycles. Note that
label: BODY

text: in case of zero noise, the extraction was complete in most cases.
label: BODY

text: Because of high sidelobes, the most unfavorable situation for extraction is a periodic sampling sequence.
label: BODY

text: In Table 3, results are also listed (in square brackets) for nonperiodic sequences characterized by the
label: BODY

text: nonperiodicity parameter σp of about 1 (corresponding to randomly distributed observation sessions).
label: BODY

text: Here, σp is the normalized root-mean-square deviation of the separation pi between the beginning times
label: BODY

text: for subsequent sessions,
label: BODY

text: σp ≡
label: BODY

text: t 1
label: BODY

text: where < p > is the average separation, < p >= PNd
label: BODY

text: pi/Nd, where Nd is the total number of (1-day-long)
label: BODY

text: observation sessions. The main eﬀect of a ﬁnite (nonzero) σp is to somewhat suppress the height of the
label: BODY

text: spectral peaks at the signal and gap intermodulation frequencies. The suppression is most eﬀective for
label: BODY

text: long sampling sequences, because (for periodically repeating sessions) the sidelobes are biggest there. For
label: BODY

text: example, for 740 data days, a 10-percent duty cycle, and a noise level of 100, the randomization increased
label: BODY

text: (Table 3) the number of extracted frequencies from 3 to 5. The randomization makes the extraction easier
label: BODY

text: to obtain if the sampling sequence is long and random.
label: BODY

text: In the majority of the simulations, the optimal frequency index was found to coincide with the frequency
label: BODY

text: of the highest spectral peak in the current Fourier map. Occasionally, however, the second or third (or
label: BODY

text: tenth) strongest peak actually produced the smallest quadratic residual function Ml, suggesting that
label: BODY

text: during the search for the optimal frequency, one should test some ﬁnite number (Np) of the biggest
label: BODY

text: spectral peaks. For the sequences tested, we have found that Np ≤50 was quite suﬃcient. The fact that
label: BODY

text: only a relatively small number of candidate l’s need to be inspected makes the minimization of the Ml
label: BODY

text: rather eﬃcient. For Np inspected peaks, the CPU time scales as Nc × Np × N × log N, where Nc is the
label: BODY

text: number of iterations (typically not higher than several tens), and where N × log N is the scale factor for
label: BODY

text: CPU time for FFT of data arrays of dimension N. (If all indices l were to be tested, the CPU time would
label: BODY

text: scale as Nc N 2 log N, which for large arrays would be excessive.) For Nc = 8, Np = 10, and N = 1018,
label: BODY

text: the CPU time was about 1 minute on a VAX 3000/400 and several minutes on a VAX 4000/90.
label: BODY

text: B. Noninteger Frequency Index
label: HH1

text: The precision of the extracted frequencies aﬀects the accuracy of the extracted phase and, ultimately,
label: BODY

text: the success of retrieving oscillatory components with lower amplitudes. To improve the extraction accu-
label: BODY

text: racy, the total length of the sampling sequence T can be increased (by padding it with zeroes) to a higher
label: BODY

text: power of two. Or, if the array size is limited, a second version of the algorithm can be used that involves
label: BODY

text: nonintegral l’s. This noninteger version is especially useful if, in addition to high frequencies, the data
label: BODY

text: contain slowly varying signals (for τ on the order of or longer than T, the resolution τ 2/T resulting from
label: BODY

text: the use of the standard discrete FFT would be on the order of or greater than τ itself). The use of the
label: BODY

text: noninteger algorithm allows for elimination of strong low-frequency components before the extraction of
label: BODY

text: high-frequency components.
label: BODY

text: If the data include frequencies not equal to an integer multiple of 1/N, the residual is minimum for
label: BODY

text: a set ±(l + ∆l), where 0 ≤∆l ≤1. The noninteger algorithm searches for the optimal ∆l by using a
label: BODY

text: noninteger FFT together with a minimization scheme that does not require construction of derivatives.
label: BODY

text: The main mathematical basis for the algorithm is described in the Appendix. The noninteger algorithm
label: BODY

text: was tested by using the same simulated data as for the integer algorithm. The results were similar in that
label: BODY

text: when one algorithm met with success, so did the other algorithm. The trade-oﬀwas a bigger array size
label: BODY

text: for the integer algorithm versus longer CPU time for the noninteger algorithm. To achieve a fractional
label: BODY

text: accuracy of δτ/τ for an oscillatory signal with the period τ, the array size (i.e., the total length of the
label: BODY

text: sampling sequence T) used by the integer algorithm must be greater than τ(τ/δτ). For the noninteger
label: BODY

text: algorithm, the required array size is less; however, the CPU time is increased due to the use of the
label: BODY

text: search and minimization procedure that optimizes ∆l. For the eight oscillatory components in Table 2,
label: BODY

text: CPU time for the noninteger algorithm was typically a factor of 10 bigger, while the frequency accuracy
label: BODY

text: increased by one signiﬁcant place for the same array size in both algorithms.
label: BODY

text: The principal application of the noninteger algorithm is for spectral analysis of data with both rapid
label: BODY

text: and slow modulations present. To simulate a train of hourly residuals of Earth orientation parameters
label: BODY

text: obtained from reduced VLBI data, the simulated data consisted of the same four near-diurnal and four
label: BODY

text: near-semidiurnal oscillatory frequencies as in Table 2, superimposed on a slowly varying signal that was
label: BODY

text: represented by a sum of 1-month, 1-year, and 18-year periodic components. The signal was imbedded
label: BODY

text: in a background of Gaussian noise on the same order of magnitude as the strongest diurnal component.
label: BODY

text: The extraction success depends on the length and structure of the sampling sequence, noise level, and
label: BODY

text: the number and amplitudes of low-frequency components. A typical sampling sequence consisted of 270
label: BODY

text: data days (data sampled hourly) separated by 4-day-long gaps (with a corresponding duty cycle of 0.2
label: BODY

text: and a total sampling sequence length of T = 3.5 yr). Table 4 summarizes the simulation parameters for
label: BODY

text: three cases: In the ﬁrst case, the amplitudes of the 1-month, 1-year, and 18-year components were 500,
label: BODY

text: 2000, and 0, respectively; in the second case, the amplitudes were 500, 2000, and 200,000, respectively;
label: BODY

text: in the third case, the amplitudes were 500, 20,000, and 500,000, respectively. The noise level was 30, and
label: BODY

text: the eight diurnal and semidiurnal signals were the same as in Table 2 (amplitudes between 3.2 and 23).
label: BODY

text: Figures 2, 3, and 4 show the corresponding original data and the original, residual, and clean Fourier
label: BODY

text: maps. On comparison, the ﬁgures illustrate the eﬀect of the number and amplitudes of low-frequency
label: BODY

text: components on the success of extraction of high-frequency components.
label: BODY

text: Table 4. Extraction results when the data also contained strong
label: H4

text: low-frequency components (corresponding to Figs.
label: BODY

text: and 4).a
label: BODY

text: Relative ampitudes of
label: BODY

text: Iterations for extraction of
label: BODY

text: low-frequency components
label: BODY

text: high-frequency components
label: BODY

text: a The listed numbers designate iterations that extracted one of the
label: BODY

text: high-frequency components.
label: BODY

text: The high-frequency components
label: BODY

text: are the same as in Table 2, the number of data days was 270
label: BODY

text: (data sampled hourly), the duty cycle was 0.2, and the noise
label: BODY

text: level was 30.
label: BODY

text: In Figs. 2–4, iterative application of the algorithm has resulted in successful extractions of the diurnal
label: BODY

text: and semidiurnal frequencies in all cases; however, the extraction process was lengthier (resulting in richer
label: BODY

text: recovered spectral content) when the number and amplitudes of the original low-frequency components
label: BODY

text: were higher. In general, the algorithm ﬁnds the strongest (in these cases, the low-frequency) components
label: BODY

text: ﬁrst. However, since the values of the extracted frequencies and phase are always somewhat in error (the
label: BODY

text: accuracy will eventually be limited by the available numerical accuracy), the eﬀect of errors in the values
label: BODY

text: of the extracted parameters is made up by retrieving, in successive iterations, additional (false) frequen-
label: BODY

text: cies, until the slow variations are matched suﬃciently well for the high-frequency modulations to become
label: BODY

text: the strongest Fourier components in the current residual map. This process of matching the time sequence
label: BODY

text: with a richer Fourier spectrum becomes more intricate with increasing amplitudes and complexity of the
label: BODY

text: original spectrum. In Fig. 2, the original spectrum contains no 18-year component. The high-frequency
label: BODY

text: signals were found immediately after the low (1-year and 1-month) frequency signals, except that (due
label: BODY

text: to a ﬁnite length T of the data array) the algorithm also found (as it usually does when variations on
label: BODY

text: a scale comparable to or longer that T are present) a frequency ≃1/T. In Figs. 3 and 4, the original
label: BODY

text: spectrum includes an 18-year-long component with the amplitude four orders of magnitude higher than

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the strongest diurnal component. The algorithm also ﬁts the slow variations ﬁrst. However, because the
label: BODY

text: variations are not ﬁt exactly (the 18-year period was found with 2- and 3-percent accuracy in Figs. 3
label: BODY

text: and 4, respectively, and the 1-year and 1-month periods were found with 0.7- and 0.1-percent accuracy,
label: BODY

text: respectively), the algorithm continues to search for additional frequencies until the ﬁt is suﬃciently tight.
label: BODY

text: In Figs. 3 and 4, the high frequencies were extracted at the 11th, 14th, 15th, 18th, 20th, 22nd, 25th,
label: BODY

text: and 31st iterations, and at the 26th, 28th, 31st, 47th, 53rd, 65th, 72nd, and 86th iterations, respectively.
label: BODY

text: Thus, the complexity of the low-frequency content will play a signiﬁcant role in establishing limits on the
label: BODY

text: algorithm applicability.
label: BODY

text: IV. Summary and Conclusions
label: HH1

text: A new algorithm has been developed for spectral analysis of sparse, irregularly sampled data with
label: BODY

text: low signal-to-noise ratios; the extracted parameters include frequency, phase, and amplitude of the signal
label: BODY

text: components. The algorithm identiﬁes the strongest component as that component which when passed
label: BODY

text: through the same sampling sequence as the original data produces a Fourier image that is best matched
label: BODY

text: to the current residual map. The algorithm has met with success in trials with simulated data, including
label: BODY

text: those of a type similar to hourly residuals for Earth orientation parameters. The simulated data consisted
label: BODY

text: of four near-diurnal and four semidiurnal oscillatory components with amplitudes varying by an order of
label: BODY

text: magnitude. The background noise was on the same order of magnitude as the strongest high-frequency
label: BODY

text: component. The number of data days ranged from 70 to 740 (data sampled hourly), and the duty cycle
label: BODY

text: for the observation sessions varied between 1 and 0.1. Two versions of the algorithm were developed. In
label: BODY

text: the integer version, the frequency solution is limited to 1/T, where T is the sampling sequence length.
label: BODY

text: With only the high-frequency components present in the data, the integer version was successful in
label: BODY

text: extracting all components with an amplitude–noise ratio greater than about 0.2; the extraction success
label: BODY

text: was higher (less) for longer (shorter) data sequences and higher (lower) duty cycles. Sessions that are
label: BODY

text: not periodic make the extraction easier to achieve since the sidelobes (produced by the interference with
label: BODY

text: the average periodicity of the sessions) are less than for the periodic case. Sidelobes associated with
label: BODY

text: one frequency can contribute signal at other frequencies. If the residual map has been constructed by
label: BODY

text: completely subtracting the identiﬁed spectral peak, the subtracted sidelobes can produce errors in this
label: BODY

text: and other estimates. The solution to this problem is to subtract the peak in fractions. That is, at multiple
label: BODY

text: applications of the algorithm, one subtracts from the current residual map only a fraction of the image
label: BODY

text: that has been constructed by using the peak full strength. The eﬀect of subtracted fractions on the
label: BODY

text: extraction results could be used to achieve conﬁdence in the found solutions. Another test of conﬁdence
label: BODY

text: can be obtained by modifying the observation strategy, e.g., by changing the duty cycle, the length of
label: BODY

text: the sampling sequence, and the gap randomness. The frequency resolution can be increased by padding
label: BODY

text: the data array with zeroes to a higher power of two (higher T).
label: BODY

text: For signal frequencies that are not integer multiples of the minimum discrete FFT frequency, the
label: BODY

text: residual map will be minimized by a noninteger frequency value. We have implemented (and tested)
label: BODY

text: an algorithm version that searches for a noninteger frequency index. The resolution is greatly improved
label: BODY

text: over 1/T without requiring an increase in the array length. However, the CPU time is increased. In
label: BODY

text: simulations with diurnal and semidiurnal bands, the typical CPU time was longer by a factor of 10,
label: BODY

text: while the extracted frequency accuracy increased by one signiﬁcant place relative to results obtained
label: BODY

text: with the integer algorithm.
label: BODY

text: Many real data also contain (in addition to the high frequencies) very
label: BODY

text: strong low-frequency components. Unless some other scheme is used to eliminate the slow variations
label: BODY

text: ﬁrst, when applied, the algorithm ﬁts the slowly varying signal with low frequencies before it searches
label: BODY

text: for the high frequencies.
label: BODY

text: The increase in the extraction accuracy comes at the expense of increased
label: BODY

text: CPU time. The CPU time is increased depending on the signal frequencies, strength, and number of
label: BODY

text: low-frequency components. Several types of simulated data with strong 18-year, 1-year, and 1-month
label: BODY

text: periodic components were analyzed in detail in Section III.B (Figs. 2, 3, and 4). The accuracy of the
label: BODY

text: extracted frequencies inﬂuences the eﬃciency of retrieval of components with lower amplitudes.
label: BODY

text: For uniformly spaced time markers, the CPU time scales as a constant ×Nc × Np × N × log N, where
label: BODY

text: Nc is a number of iterations of the algorithm (to ﬁnd multiple oscillatory components), Np is a number
label: BODY

text: of candidate spectral peaks that must be inspected to minimize the residual sum, and N is the array
label: BODY

text: total size chosen as a power of 2. For 218 time markers in the sampling sequence and eight cleaning steps,
label: BODY

text: typical CPU time for the integer algorithm was on the order of several minutes on a VAX-class machine.
label: BODY

text: For the noninteger algorithm, the CPU time can exceed several hours, depending on the complexity of
label: BODY

text: the overall frequency content.
label: BODY

text: The algorithm is currently applied to actual hourly Earth orientation parameters for the available
label: BODY

text: International Radio Interferometric Surveying (IRIS), Crustal Dynamics Project (CDP), and DSN VLBI
label: BODY

text: data.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Appendix
label: HH1

text: Spectral Analysis for a Noninteger Frequency Index
label: BODY

text: The method outlined in Section II is frequently suﬃcient provided that the periodic components are
label: BODY

text: suﬃciently few in number, well separated in frequency, not too disparate in the relative magnitude of
label: BODY

text: their amplitudes, and not too corrupted by the presence of noise. If stressing conditions are present, the
label: BODY

text: method can be enhanced by introducing fractional frequencies. The Fourier map becomes a function of
label: BODY

text: the fractional value ∆l. An additional search is performed on ∆l to identify the residual minimum by
label: BODY

text: using some standard function minimum-ﬁnding algorithm.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: of Eq. (A-1) represents a signal at the candidate frequency ωl+∆l = 2π(l + ∆l)/(Nδt), and f S
label: BODY

text: l+∆l(k)
label: BODY

text: is the Fourier transform of fl+∆l(tn) S(tn), where the periodic function fl+∆l(tn) ≡exp(−2π i(n(l +
label: BODY

text: As in the main text, the optimal value of l+∆l is found as that frequency which when ﬁltered through
label: BODY

text: the same sampling sequence S(tn) as the original data provides the best match to the original Fourier
label: BODY

text: map. The algorithm computes the Fourier map, DS(k), selects a value of ∆l, 0 ≤∆l ≤1, and, for the
label: BODY

text: selected ∆l, computes the functions f S
label: BODY

text: l+∆l(k). To evaluate Ml+∆l, the values of the amplitudes al+∆l are
label: BODY

text: determined from the following least-square minimization principle:

text: For m = ±(l+∆l), Eq. (A-2) deﬁnes a linear system of two equations from which the optimal magnitudes
label: BODY

text: of the unknown a±(l+∆l)’s are determined. By using these optimal a±(l+∆l)’s in Eq. (A-1), the algorithm
label: BODY

text: searches for an optimal l that minimizes Ml. (Similar to that in the main text, this minimization is
label: BODY

text: most eﬃciently achieved by inspecting several of the highest peaks in the original Fourier map.) The
label: BODY

text: above-described procedure yields an optimal l for any given ∆l. The algorithm performs a systematic
label: BODY

text: search for a ∆l that minimizes Ml+∆l as a function of ∆l by using Brent’s method (it does not require
label: BODY

text: construction of derivatives; see [1]).
label: BODY
